posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I am speaking as me…and not a mentor:

I have questions.  I get the increase due to tariffs.  And $18 isn’t bad per se for a 60.  I am “concerned” on the $23 increase on the 44.

Admittedly…I don’t know the performance of the 44 that well.  I have heard it is a strong performer.   However, giving it such an increase…to me raises questions.

Like, can I use it as a drive motor?  Or as a primary motor for elevator?  I mean…for that jump on price…I am surprised drivetrains and teams wouldn’t chose that over the 60 as a primary as a drive motor to lower the weight.

For the record…I get that the 44 is capable motor.  I will not dispute that. To increase it that much…the tariffs must have been much higher on the 44 than the 60 to bring it to that price point.

I hope that the supply issues will be kept to a minimum…as these tend to be…how shall we say…out of stock consistently.  Especially the 44s…and PowerPole Adapter Board…and…

I would like to know, what each motor capabilities are (not just the specs), like this motor can be used for this…and not used for this.  This is for teams that are not in the know (and me). I don’t want to order the wrong motor for a function and either burn it out because that it was not designed for a task ($218 down the drain) all because I or our team used the wrong tool for the wrong task.

Thanks!  Hopefully, these will not go out of stock before we can order a few in September when our budget hits.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Emerson OHara
posts.cooked:
I wouldn’t be surprised if the x44 doesn’t cost about the same as the x60 to produce. Sure the stator is less copper and steel but the rest of the package is similar and the motor controller costs are probably about the same. It may even be possible the x44 TalonFX is more expensive since it had to be redesigned into that tiny package to fit on the back of the motor.

The performance increase is that it is significantly smaller and lighter and still very capable. I would say moving forwards you will see teams move to smaller motors when they are sufficient to keep weight down given FIRST took 10lbs away and i expect that will stay.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
RicDV:

what each motor capabilities are (not just the specs), like this motor can be used for this…and not used for this

If it’s in spec, it can be used for it. There’s no secret reason you could or could not use a x44 instead of an x60. It varies from robot to robot, so it would be a fools errand for the manufacturer to determine  how each team could and couldn’t use the motor

RicDV:

like this motor can be used for this…and not used for this.

I feel like this is a better question for a different thread about motor selection for mechanisms to be honest. I see zero reason why this motor wouldn’t be used by teams for all sorts of mechanisms. I haven’t seen them used as the drive motor in a swerve, but definitely seen them for steering. They’re everywhere on manipulators and elevator systems.

I’d assume a newer motor for wcp has more sunk costs that are reflected in the higher price, if they recouped x60 production costs prior to tariffs.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Is there a difference in performance between a Corvette and Chevette?  They are both cars.  They both have engines.  They are both from the same company.  Does that make them the same?  Not a proper analogy…both have Vette in the name so I used it.

I understand your points.  They are valid.  To price them the same as they were equals when last year they were $5 off of each other…that is a stretch.  Even before this…I honestly felt it was too close in price.  IF I had to decide (for drive train) between the two…I would buy the 60s.  Not because it was better…just because it would make sense to me.  A $5 difference that a difference.  Had it been a $15 or $20 difference…then I would mix the two.

And now with the “narrow” variants coming out…one is forced to potentially go to a 44 for odometry…or a different brand (we will focus on Kraken).  Some are wanting something…smaller.  Using the SDS 5n as an example…they are pretty much “mandating” 60/44 combo when it comes to Kraken (it even looks like the 44 is the only acceptable steering motor regardless of what the drive is). I am not sure what ThriftyBot is going to do (we are looking at the Narrow once it comes out and deciding).

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

If it’s in spec

This right here.  IF is the biggest word in the English language.  It becomes subjective.  IF I were to use it out of spec…and no one tells me it was an out of spec issue:   Am I truly at fault?  IF I don’t know…and it wasn’t said I can’t do it…am I truly at fault?

The rest I agree with.  Common sense would say for me not to use a 44 for a drive motor unless I was under say 50 pounds with bumper and battery.  Or just running the drive base.  I can see this then.

I used specific systems for a reason.  They are expected to do more…and carry more.  They require endurance and power.  This not to say the 44 cannot produce or work.  There are limitations.  Much like the word IF.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
The easiest way to approach this when teams ask me personally.

Do I need weight? No? Use an X60 everywhere they’ll have better thermals and harder to fail.

Do I need weight? No? Use an X60 everywhere they’ll have better thermals and harder to fail.

Do I need weight? Am I out of room? Yes? Use an X44 but know you’ll have to do some legwork and testing for your specific application.

Do I need weight? Am I out of room? Yes? Use an X44 but know you’ll have to do some legwork and testing for your specific application.

Recalc or jvn calc are good places to start for guessing current draw, loads etc…I believe there is a presentation regarding sizing motors per application?

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
RicDV:

Admittedly…I don’t know the performance of the 44 that well. I have heard it is a strong performer. However, giving it such an increase…to me raises questions.

Like, can I use it as a drive motor? Or as a primary motor for elevator? I mean…for that jump on price…I am surprised drivetrains and teams wouldn’t chose that over the 60 as a primary as a drive motor to lower the weight.

On paper the x44s are roughly comparable to a Falcon 500 (at least in terms of Stall Current, Peak Power, etc), but the biggest difference you’ll see is the x44s have a much lower thermal mass, meaning they’re far more likely to hit the thermal limit and shut down under continuous load than an x60 or an older Falcon 500 would.

That’s not to say the x44s aren’t still useful, we used them a bunch of them all over our robot this year, but I would hesitate to use them as a drive motor (though swerve steering is fine) or for an elevator that has to hold a position under stall for an extended period (we tried x44s on our elevator and had to swap them for x60s), though the new REV Max Planetary Brake may solve that problem.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I understand there is a time and a place for everything.  I get it.  Me, I like testing safe…and learning from others failures (those that can afford them).  Not that I would have a reason for doing so…I wouldn’t put a swerve module with 2 44s in it, for a total of 8 on a bot that was the same weight of this last seasons bot.  I have been called crazy because I jumped out of aircraft for a living…however…at 218 a whack and a finite budget…I am not that crazy!

I get that each motor is “designed” for certain things.  I fully understand that.  IF I don’t don’t want extra weight on an arm that is reaching out…smaller motor…or belt or chain to decrease the max weight for intended use.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Nick Coussens
posts.cooked:
The steering power on swerve is a great application for the X44. I personally used (and designed) the X2S(t) modules on 33’s robot this past year and had no issues with the X44 being the steering motor.

In the past, I have used a Neo550, and even an RS550 motor for the same application, and teams like 2767 having been doing something similar for a long time.

posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.cooked: Why would the size of the motor make production of it worth that much less especially when it is a newer product comparable in function to larger motors like a Falcon 500? This logic isn’t really lining up. If anything going smaller in many cases can add production costs due to other components that need to change. Shrinking technology costs money too, at least in theory. Don’t forget there’s a controller on the back of this thing.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Given the cost of the original NEO, NEO 550, Minion, and even the Vortex to some degree, it’s clear a big portion (probably the majority) of the cost for integrated controller motors like Krakens is the controller, rather than the brushless motor itself. Given the controllers for both x44 and x60 likely share many of the same parts (though with the x44 being the harder to package of the two), it makes some sense the prices would be similar.
For sure, that’s my point - I’d think shrinking electronics adds engineering and production costs. Pile tariffs on top and well…

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I get what you are saying.  Are you doing your swerve drive base with only 44s or are you doing it a mix?  I am going to presume a mix.  And I am not mad about doing a mix.  IF it came right down to it…I would do it as a mix.

You compared it to a Falcon.  We used Falcons on steer this last year.  burned two of them.  I know the 44s have controllers on them…just like the Falcons and the 60s.

As for shrinking tech…cellphones have either stayed the same as previous years or have dropped.  All while improving the capabilities of the electronics.  Cars have gone up in price as they add more bells and whistles to them.  Most of the parts on both come from out of the country.  I am not mad or questioning this…it is what it is.

Economically, it depends on the market.  IF the market will bear that increase…it will work.  IF not…it won’t.

In FIRST , we are only able to use approved vendors, approved motors, and the list goes on.  I can’t design a motor…slap it on a bot and color it good.  It has to be approved.  It has to be tested.

One thing has stuck out to me about what you have said:  IF the electronics are the hardest thing on the 44…why wasn’t priced the same as the 60 or more before?  It would make sense.  Why wasn’t it done?  Small controllers are able to be done…for a long time now.  I can’t do it…others have.  It isn’t new tech or engineering issues.  It is a tariff issue, I will agree with that.  However, not knowing the actual tariffs between the two motors and their controllers…who is to say.  To say that a 44 is as good as a 60…only in certain applications only IF it is in spec…even if it has a controller built in (which I love and is why Kraken is my choice to use), you aren’t going stick a 4 or 6 cylinder in a Corvette and call it an improved Corvette.  It is like calling the MACH-E a Mustang…it isn’t in my books.  I am not even a Ford fan.

The 60 is beefier than the 44 regardless of tech.  We can’t compare it to the Falcon because…it is no longer produced.  And the ones that are still out there are dwindling in numbers due to age or breaking down.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
